issues.title: Oil Leaks (Chain Housing and Case Seams)
issues.symptoms: Oil spots under car, oil on engine surfaces, visible seepage, low oil level, burning oil smell
issues.description: The 964's M64 engine is notorious for oil leaks. The most common source is the chain housing gasket (timing chain cover), but oil also seeps from the case half seams, valve cover gaskets, oil cooler seals, and cam tower o-rings. While some seepage is considered normal for air-cooled engines, excessive leaks require attention.
fixes: Chain housing (timing cover) gasket replacement - most common leak
Case seam resealing requires engine removal
Valve cover gaskets - relatively accessible
Oil cooler hose and fitting inspection
Cam tower o-rings (requires cam housing removal)
Use correct Porsche sealant for case seams

repairCosts.notes: Chain housings, valve covers, and cam towers common.

issues.title: Dual-Mass Flywheel Failure
issues.symptoms: Clutch chatter, vibration at idle in gear, rattling noise, difficulty engaging gears
issues.description: The 964 was the first 911 to use a dual-mass flywheel (DMF) to smooth out the flat-six's inherent vibration. These flywheels have internal springs and dampers that wear out over time, causing chatter and vibration. A failed DMF can also damage the clutch and transmission input shaft bearing.
fixes: Replace dual-mass flywheel with OEM or single-mass conversion
Single-mass conversion popular but increases drivetrain NVH
Replace clutch and throw-out bearing at the same time
Inspect transmission input shaft bearing while apart
Consider lightweight flywheel for track use

repairCosts.notes: DMF failure requires trans removal. Convert to single mass optional.

issues.title: Distributor and Ignition Problems
issues.symptoms: Hard starting, misfires, rough running, stalling, no spark
issues.description: The 964 uses twin distributors driven off the camshafts. The distributor caps, rotors, and internal components wear over time. The distributor drive gears (plastic in early cars) can strip. Moisture intrusion causes cap corrosion and misfires. The dual-distributor system is complex but essential for the engine's operation.
fixes: Replace distributor caps and rotors (quality Bosch parts)
Inspect and replace distributor drive gear if worn
Check and clean all ignition connections
Replace spark plug wires if original
Upgrade to brass distributor gear (if equipped with plastic)

repairCosts.notes: DME trigger failure. Rebuilt units available.

issues.title: Power Steering System Issues
issues.symptoms: Whining pump, heavy steering, fluid leaks, lack of assist, groaning noise
issues.description: The 964 was the first 911 with standard power steering. The hydraulic system includes a pump, rack, reservoir, and lines that all age. Power steering pump failure is common, as are leaks from the rack seals, high-pressure lines, and return lines. The fluid should be changed regularly.
fixes: Power steering pump rebuild or replacement
Replace leaking high-pressure and return hoses
Rack seal replacement or rack rebuild
Fluid flush and fill (use correct Pentosin fluid)
Check and clean reservoir screen

issues.title: G50 Transmission Synchro Wear
issues.symptoms: Grinding when shifting, difficulty engaging gears, blocked shifts, gear pop-out
issues.description: The 964 uses the Getrag G50 5-speed transmission. While generally robust, the synchros wear over time, especially second gear. Aggressive driving, improper fluid, and inadequate warm-up accelerate wear. A worn synchro will grind or block when trying to engage the affected gear.
fixes: Regular transmission fluid changes (GL-4 or Swepco 201)
Synchro replacement during transmission rebuild
Proper shifting technique and full clutch engagement
Allow transmission to warm up before aggressive driving
Some owners run thicker fluid in worn transmissions

repairCosts.notes: Synchros wear (especially 2nd). Use correct GL-4 fluid.

issues.title: Cylinder Head Stud Failures
issues.symptoms: Oil leak at head, coolant seepage, compression loss, misfires
issues.description: The M64 engine can develop head stud issues, particularly the through-bolts that secure the heads to the case. These studs can pull out or stretch, especially if the engine has been overheated or has had incorrect torque applied. This is more common on Turbo models due to higher cylinder pressures.
fixes: Head stud inspection during any engine work
Proper torque procedure critical for reassembly
Helicoil repair for pulled threads (requires engine removal)
Through-bolt style studs can be replaced with Dilavar studs
Always use new hardware when reassembling

repairCosts.notes: Head stud failures on early 964. Requires engine removal.

issues.title: Air Conditioning System Problems
issues.symptoms: Weak cooling, no cold air, AC compressor noise, clutch not engaging
issues.description: The 964's air conditioning system uses R-12 refrigerant (original) and is complex due to the mid-engine layout. Compressor failures, condenser leaks, and evaporator issues are common in older systems. Many have been converted to R-134a with varying success. The AC evaporator requires dashboard removal to replace.
fixes: R-134a conversion with proper components
Compressor replacement (denso or OEM)
Condenser inspection and replacement if leaking
Evaporator replacement (major labor, dashboard out)
Receiver-drier replacement with any major AC work
System leak test before recharging

issues.title: Electrical System Problems
issues.symptoms: Gauge failures, intermittent lights, dead dashboard, alarm issues, starting problems
issues.description: The 964 introduced more electrical complexity than earlier 911s, and these systems age poorly. The DME relay is a common failure point, as are ground connections and the alarm/immobilizer system. Gauge clusters develop cold solder joints. Wiring in the engine bay becomes brittle from heat.
fixes: DME relay replacement (common failure)
Clean and resecure ground connections
Gauge cluster solder repair
Alarm system bypass or repair
Inspect and repair brittle wiring in engine compartment
Central electric panel inspection

repairCosts.notes: DME and relay issues. Grounds important.

guides.title: Complete Suspension Refresh
guides.description: Full front and rear suspension rebuild for the 964, restoring proper handling to this torsion bar-equipped 911. Addresses worn bushings, shocks, and steering components common on 30+ year old examples.
guides.interval: Every 60,000-80,000 miles or when handling degrades
tools: Floor jack and jack stands rated for vehicle weight
Pickle fork or ball joint separator
steps: Raise vehicle and support securely on jack stands under reinforced jacking points.
Remove all four wheels and set aside in safe location.
Begin with front suspension - disconnect sway bar end links (18mm).
Remove tie rod ends from steering knuckle using pickle fork.
Support the strut assembly before disconnecting from knuckle.
Remove strut pinch bolt and disconnect from knuckle.
From above, remove the three 13mm nuts holding strut top mount.
Remove strut assembly and replace with new unit or rebuild with new cartridge.
Mark and count turns on torsion bar adjusters for ride height reference.
Remove front control arms - note shim placement for camber settings.
Press out old bushings and press in new ones, or replace entire arms.
For rear suspension, remove trailing arm bolts and lower arms.
Replace trailing arm bushings using press - original bushings are rubber.
Spring plate bushings require removal of torsion bar cover plates.
Replace rear shock absorbers - access from wheel well opening.
Reassemble in reverse order, torquing all fasteners to spec.
Front control arm bolts: 63 ft-lbs (85 Nm) - tighten with weight on wheels.
Tie rod ends: 33 ft-lbs (45 Nm) with new cotter pins.
Install wheels and torque lug bolts to 96 ft-lbs (130 Nm).
Perform wheel alignment after completing all work.
tips: The 964 uses torsion bars front and rear - handle with care and note settings.
Elephant Racing makes excellent polyurethane upgrades for street/track use.
Original rubber bushings are adequate for street use with OEM handling feel.
Mark all adjustment points and count turns for ride height reference.
Consider Bilstein HD or Koni adjustables for improved handling.
Check CV boots while suspension is disassembled - common failure point.
The 964's power steering adds complexity - don't disturb hydraulic lines unless necessary.
warnings: Torsion bars are under significant tension - improper removal can cause injury.
The 964 weighs approximately 3,000 lbs - use appropriate jack stands.
Mark or photograph all adjustment settings before disassembly.
Some fasteners may require heat due to corrosion on 30+ year old cars.
Power steering fluid can damage paint - protect body panels.
Always tighten suspension fasteners with weight on wheels for proper bushing loading.

guides.title: Rust Prevention and Repair
guides.description: Comprehensive guide to inspecting, preventing, and repairing rust on the 964. Covers common problem areas including rocker panels, floor pans, battery box, and suspension mounting points critical to this classic air-cooled 911.
guides.laborHours: Varies significantly by extent of rust
tools: Wire brush and wire wheel attachments
Angle grinder with cutting and grinding discs
DA sander with various grit discs
Spray gun for primer and underseal
Safety equipment: welding helmet, gloves, respirator
steps: Thoroughly clean undercarriage with pressure washer to expose rust areas.
Raise vehicle and inspect all common rust locations systematically.
Check rocker panels by pressing firmly - soft spots indicate internal rust.
Inspect battery box area (front trunk) - acid damage is common here.
Examine floor pans from inside with carpet removed and from below.
Check kidney areas where front fenders meet body - debris traps moisture.
Inspect jack point reinforcements - critical structural areas.
Examine shock tower tops from inside engine compartment.
For surface rust: sand to bare metal, treat with rust converter, prime and seal.
For perforation rust: cut out affected area 1 inch beyond visible rust.
Treat surrounding metal with rust converter before patching.
Fabricate or purchase repair panels to fit openings.
Apply weld-through primer to mating surfaces.
Tack weld panels in place, checking fit frequently.
Finish weld using stitch welding to prevent warpage.
Grind welds smooth and apply seam sealer to all joints.
Treat interior surfaces with rust preventive (POR-15 or equivalent).
Apply rubberized underseal to exterior underbody surfaces.
Prime and paint repaired areas to match existing finish.
Apply cavity wax to all hollow sections for ongoing protection.
tips: The 964 is a unibody - structural rust must be properly repaired for safety.
Battery acid damage is common - inspect even if battery has been relocated.
Kidney area rust often starts invisibly and spreads - probe thoroughly.
Original factory underseal can trap moisture - remove damaged sections.
Quality reproduction panels are available from Restoration Design and others.
POR-15 requires proper surface preparation - follow instructions exactly.
Consider professional inspection before purchasing a 964 to assess rust severity.
Cars from coastal or salt-road areas require extra diligence.
warnings: Extensive rust repair can exceed the vehicle's value - assess carefully first.
Welding near fuel lines and tank requires proper safety precautions.
Improper structural repairs can affect crash safety - consult professionals if unsure.
MIG welding thin body panels requires skill to avoid burn-through.
Rust preventive coatings require proper ventilation and safety equipment.
Disconnect battery and fuel system before any welding operations.

guides.title: Electrical System Restoration
guides.description: Complete guide to diagnosing and restoring the 964's electrical system. Covers the DME relay, fuel pump relay, ground connections, gauge cluster repair, and wiring harness inspection critical to reliable operation.
guides.interval: Inspect every 2-3 years, service as needed
tools: Small picks and probes for connectors
Torx and Phillips screwdrivers for interior panels
steps: Disconnect battery before any electrical work - negative terminal first.
Test battery condition - load test and check voltage (should be 12.6V resting).
Clean and tighten all battery connections with terminal cleaner.
Test alternator output - should be 13.8-14.4V at idle.
Locate the relay panel in the front trunk area (fuse/relay carrier).
Identify DME relay position - pull and inspect for melted contacts.
Test DME relay with multimeter - replace if any doubt (common failure).
Inspect fuel pump relay - listen for click when key turns on.
Check and clean all ground connections - critical for proper operation.
Main engine ground is at transmission - clean and retorque.
Secondary grounds on body should be cleaned to bare metal.
Inspect wiring harness for rodent damage (common on stored cars).
Check wiring in engine bay for heat damage and brittleness.
For gauge cluster issues, remove cluster (Torx screws from behind wheel).
Inspect and resolder cold solder joints on cluster circuit board.
Replace failed capacitors in cluster (common cause of gauge failure).
Test all lighting circuits - replace failed bulbs.
Inspect and clean multi-pin connectors throughout the vehicle.
Apply dielectric grease to all cleaned connections.
Reconnect battery and test all systems before closing up.
tips: The 964's DME relay is the most common cause of no-start conditions.
Keep a spare DME relay in the car - they can fail without warning.
Ground connections are critical - clean and protect with dielectric grease.
The gauge cluster capacitor kit is an inexpensive preventive repair.
Biodegradable wiring insulation attracts rodents - inspect stored cars carefully.
Consider upgrading to LED bulbs for instrument lighting - more reliable.
The 964 uses dual distributors - service both at the same time.
Document any wiring changes with photographs for future reference.
warnings: Always disconnect battery before working on electrical systems.
The 964 has airbags - wait 10 minutes after disconnecting battery before working near steering wheel.
Incorrect relay replacement can damage the DME computer.
Brittle wiring can crack when handled - be gentle with original harnesses.
Static electricity can damage electronic components - ground yourself.
Do not use excessive dielectric grease - it can attract dirt over time.

guides.title: Interior Restoration
guides.description: Comprehensive interior restoration guide for the 964. Covers leather seat repair, carpet replacement, door panel restoration, dashboard care, and HVAC system service to return the cabin to factory-fresh condition.
tools: Trim panel removal tools (plastic pry bars)
Hog ring pliers and hog rings
steps: Remove seats by unbolting from floor (4 bolts per seat, 13mm).
Disconnect any electrical connectors for power seats or seat sensors.
Inspect seat leather condition - clean with quality leather cleaner first.
For worn leather: apply Leatherique or similar conditioner system.
For cracked/torn leather: professional reupholstery or cover kit replacement.
Remove hog rings to separate leather from foam for cover replacement.
Replace foam cushions if compressed or degraded.
Install new covers using hog rings at attachment points.
Remove door panels by removing screws behind handle pulls and popping clips.
Inspect door card backing - replace water barrier if damaged.
Clean or replace door panel fabric/leather as needed.
Remove old carpet by removing sill plates and seat bases.
Clean and treat floor pan with rust preventive if any bare metal.
Install new carpet kit, starting from rear and working forward.
Secure carpet with adhesive at edges and plastic retainers.
Clean dashboard with appropriate cleaner - avoid silicone products.
Treat leather steering wheel with conditioner.
Replace shift and e-brake boots if cracked or worn.
Service HVAC system - replace blower motor if noisy or weak.
Test all interior functions before final assembly.
tips: The 964 interior is well-made - often cleaning and conditioning is sufficient.
Leatherique's two-step system can revive severely dried leather.
Original colors may be difficult to match - consider full color change if needed.
The 964 uses supple leather that responds well to conditioning.
Door panel clips are fragile - have extras on hand before removal.
Steam cleaning is effective for carpet and fabric without chemicals.
Original floor mats are collectible - preserve if possible.
Sun visors often sag due to mirror weight - rebuild kits available.
warnings: Airbag-equipped cars require care when removing steering wheel components.
Power seat wiring carries significant current - disconnect battery first.
Leather dyes can stain surrounding surfaces - mask carefully.
Silicone-based products leave residue that interferes with future repairs.
Heat gun can damage leather if held too close - keep moving.
Some adhesives require ventilation - work in well-ventilated area.

oem.name: Pelican Parts
oem.notes: Extensive 964 catalog with tech articles. The go-to resource for air-cooled 911 parts.

oem.name: Porsche Classic
oem.notes: Genuine Porsche OEM and remanufactured classic parts.

oem.name: Suncoast Porsche Parts
oem.notes: Genuine Porsche parts at discounted prices.

oem.name: FCP Euro
oem.notes: Lifetime replacement guarantee on all parts.

performance.name: Elephant Racing
performance.notes: 964 suspension specialists. Track-proven coilovers and handling upgrades.

performance.name: Wevo
performance.notes: Shifters and drivetrain upgrades. Excellent short shifter kits.

performance.name: LN Engineering
performance.notes: Air-cooled engine components. Cylinders, pistons, and IMS solutions.

performance.name: Fabspeed
performance.notes: Performance exhaust systems and headers for 964.

general.name: Sierra Madre Collection
general.notes: Complete Porsche parts inventory. Quality parts for all 911 generations.

general.name: Stoddard Porsche Parts
general.notes: Vintage Porsche specialists. Authentic and reproduction parts.

specialty.name: Rennsport Systems
specialty.notes: Air-cooled 911 specialists. Engine rebuilds and performance builds.

used.name: 911UK Classifieds
used.notes: UK-based 911 marketplace. Good for Euro-spec parts.

used.name: eBay Motors
used.notes: Large selection of used and NOS 964 parts.

tools.name: P101tv VIN Decoder
tools.notes: Porsche VIN decoder and options codes

engine.notes: Hold one end while torquing the other

diyGuides.title: Oil Change
diyGuides.description: Complete oil and filter change procedure for the M64 air-cooled flat-six.
tools: Oil filter wrench (various types may be needed)
Ramps or jack and jack stands
steps: Warm the engine for 2-3 minutes - oil flows better when warm.
Drive onto ramps or raise and support the car safely.
Locate the main oil drain plug on the bottom of the engine case.
Position large drain pan and remove the 21mm drain plug.
Allow oil to drain completely - 15-20 minutes for thorough drainage.
The 964 has a spin-on oil filter located in the engine compartment.
Access the filter from the engine bay - it's on the left side of the engine.
Using filter wrench, remove the old filter.
Apply fresh oil to the new filter's gasket.
Thread new filter on by hand until seated, then 3/4 turn more.
Replace the copper crush washer on the drain plug.
Reinstall drain plug and torque to 37 ft-lbs (50 Nm).
Add 10-11 quarts of 15W-50 or 20W-50 oil through the oil filler.
Start engine and check for leaks at drain and filter.
Let engine idle briefly, shut off, wait 3 minutes, check level.
tips: Air-cooled 911s have large oil capacity (10-11 quarts) for cooling.
Use quality 15W-50 or 20W-50 conventional or synthetic oil.
Check for oil leaks at valve covers and chain housings while working.
Some owners use Mobil 1 15W-50 or Brad Penn racing oil.

diyGuides.title: Brake Pad Replacement
diyGuides.description: Front and rear brake pad replacement on the 964's four-piston calipers.
steps: Loosen lug bolts while the car is on the ground.
Raise and support the car safely on jack stands.
Remove wheel to access the caliper.
The 964 uses four-piston fixed calipers - pads slide out without removing caliper.
Remove the pad retaining pins (cross pins through the caliper).
Use a flathead screwdriver to push and slide the old pads out.
Inspect rotor for scoring, cracks, or minimum thickness markings.
Clean the caliper pad contact surfaces with brake cleaner.
Use the piston spreader tool to push all four pistons back evenly.
Apply brake grease to the back of new pads.
Slide new pads into the caliper, ensuring proper orientation.
Reinstall pad retaining pins.
Reinstall wheel and torque lug bolts to 96 ft-lbs (130 Nm).
Repeat for all corners.
Pump brake pedal until firm before driving.
tips: Four-piston calipers require all pistons pushed back evenly.
Open brake fluid reservoir before compressing pistons.
Use quality pads from Pagid, Hawk, or Porsche OEM.
Bed new pads with gradual stops - avoid hard braking for 100 miles.

diyGuides.title: Distributor Cap and Rotor
diyGuides.description: Replace distributor caps and rotors on both dual distributors.
tools: New caps, rotors, and dust covers
steps: The 964 has two distributors - one for each cylinder bank (1-3-5 and 2-4-6).
Locate both distributors at the rear of the engine, driven off the camshafts.
Mark or photograph the spark plug wire positions before removal.
Remove the spark plug wires by pulling on the boots, not the wires.
Remove the distributor cap retaining clips or screws.
Lift off the old distributor cap.
Pull the old rotor straight off the distributor shaft.
Remove the dust cover (if equipped) beneath the rotor.
Install new dust cover.
Install new rotor - it only fits one way on the shaft.
Install new distributor cap and secure with clips/screws.
Apply dielectric grease to the inside of plug wire boots.
Reconnect spark plug wires in the correct order.
Repeat for the second distributor.
Start engine and verify smooth operation.
tips: Always use Bosch or OEM quality caps and rotors.
Note the firing order: 1-6-2-4-3-5 with cylinders numbered from front.
Inspect the distributor gear for wear while the cap is off.
Replace spark plug wires if they show cracking or corrosion.

diyGuides.title: Valve Adjustment
diyGuides.description: Check and adjust valve clearances on the M64 flat-six engine.
steps: Engine must be cold - valves expand when hot, changing clearances.
Remove the valve covers on both cylinder banks (six 10mm nuts each).
Rotate engine to TDC on cylinder 1 using 24mm socket on crank pulley.
At TDC #1, both lobes on cylinder 1 point away from the valves.
Check intake clearance: 0.10mm (0.004in) cold.
Check exhaust clearance: 0.10mm (0.004in) cold.
To adjust: Loosen 13mm locknut, turn 8mm adjuster, retighten locknut.
Recheck clearance after tightening - locknut can shift adjustment.
Rotate engine 120° to next firing order cylinder.
Firing order is 1-6-2-4-3-5 - adjust in this sequence.
Check and adjust all 12 valves (6 intake, 6 exhaust).
Clean valve cover mating surfaces and install new gaskets.
Reinstall valve covers and torque to 11 ft-lbs (15 Nm).
tips: Slight drag on feeler gauge is correct - not too tight, not too loose.
Mark each valve as you adjust to track progress.
Cylinder 1 is at the front right (passenger side, front).
Too tight = burned valves; too loose = noisy, poor performance.

engine.name: Perform valve adjustment
engine.description: Air-cooled engines require periodic valve adjustment

engine.name: Inspect/replace heat exchangers
engine.description: Critical for cabin heat, can rust through

engine.name: Reseal engine case
engine.description: Common oil leaks at case halves and covers

cooling.name: Service engine oil cooler
cooling.description: Front-mounted, clean fins for proper cooling

fuel.name: Replace rubber fuel lines
fuel.description: Deteriorate and can cause leaks or fire

fuel.name: Clean/replace fuel injectors
fuel.description: CIS-E or DME depending on year

body.name: Replace door and window seals
body.description: Reduce wind noise and water leaks

body.name: Inspect for hidden rust
body.description: Rocker panels, floor pans, battery box

interior.name: Restore leather seats
interior.description: Common wear on bolsters and stitching

buyersGuide.overview: The Porsche 964 (1989-1994) represents the first significant modernization of the 911 platform. While maintaining the classic air-cooled flat-six and rear-engine layout, the 964 added coil-spring suspension, power steering, ABS brakes, and available all-wheel drive (Carrera 4). The 3.6L engine produced 247-315 hp depending on variant. The 964 is often considered the last of the 'classic' 911s while offering more refinement than earlier models. Values have risen significantly as the air-cooled market has matured, making careful selection essential.

variants.name: Carrera 2
variants.description: Rear-wheel drive variant with 247 hp. Lighter and more pure driving experience than C4. The driver's choice.

variants.name: Carrera 4
variants.description: All-wheel drive with sophisticated viscous coupling. Heavier but more stable. First year of 964 production.

variants.name: RS / RS America
variants.description: Lightweight homologation specials. European RS had 260 hp, RS America was a stripped Carrera 2. Both are collectible.

variants.name: Turbo (965)
variants.description: The iconic widebody with 3.3L (320 hp) or 3.6L (355 hp) turbocharged flat-six. Serious performance and serious maintenance.

variants.name: Targa / Cabriolet
variants.description: Open-top variants. Targa has removable roof panel, Cabriolet is full convertible. Less rigid but popular.

items.detail: Air-cooled 911s leak oil - some is normal. Check chain housings, valve covers, and case halves for excessive leaks.
The dual-row timing chains have spring-loaded tensioners. Listen for chain rattle on cold start.
Have a compression and leak-down test performed. Should be within 5% across cylinders.
Check for smooth idle and proper fuel mixture. The Bosch Motronic system is reliable but sensors fail.
Check for shaft play, boost leaks, and wastegate operation. K26/K27 turbos are expensive to rebuild.
Test all gears. The G50 5-speed is robust but synchros can wear. Check for popping out of gear.
Test engagement - should be smooth and grab mid-travel. Clutch replacement is labor-intensive.
Listen for clicking in turns. Check boot condition for tears.
Test for proper engagement. Check for differential noise. System adds complexity.
964 introduced coil springs. Check for leaking shocks and worn bushings.
Check for leaks from pump, rack, and lines. Listen for whining indicating low fluid.
Front and rear bushings wear. Check for play and cracking.
Jack up each corner and check for play. Listen for grinding while driving.
Check rocker panels, floor pans (especially under battery), and around windshield. Earlier cars rust more.
964 uses biodegradable wire sheathing that rodents love. Check for damage.
Check for leaks and proper seal condition on open-top models.
Climate control can be complex. Test all functions including A/C.

project.description: Cars needing engine work or with significant issues. Still valuable due to air-cooled premiums.

driver.description: Running and driving with some needs. Good entry point for air-cooled ownership.

excellent.description: Well-maintained Carrera 2 or C4 with documentation. Clean examples.

concours.description: RS, RS America, or exceptional Turbo models. Low miles, fully documented.

redFlags: Oil smoke indicating worn engine internals
Timing chain rattle on cold start
Evidence of water damage or flooding
Structural rust in rockers or shock towers
Turbo models with boost control issues
whatToLookFor: Carrera 2 manual for purest driving experience
Complete service records from Porsche specialists
Recent major service (clutch, timing chains if needed)
expertTips: The 964 is the most affordable air-cooled 911 entry point currently
Carrera 2 is preferred by drivers, C4 is more forgiving in bad weather
Oil leaks are normal - excessive leaks are not. Learn the difference.
Find a Porsche specialist or independent shop that knows air-cooled cars
Factor in the cost of a pre-purchase inspection by an expert
RS America values have skyrocketed - verify authenticity carefully
The G50 transmission is robust and parts are available
Join Rennlist.com and Pelican Parts forums for excellent technical support
Budget for consumables like motor mounts and suspension bushings
A well-maintained 964 will last indefinitely with proper care

youtube.name: PCA YouTube
youtube.description: Porsche Club of America buyer guides and tech tips

websites.name: P101tv Resources
websites.description: Porsche VIN decoder, options codes, and guides
